_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary
1.0 SOURCE AND PROCESS DESCRIPTION
1.1 SOURCE
The Prairie Farms Ice Cream facility in Decatur, Illinois is subject to the USEPA's Risk Management Program (RMP) for Accidental Chemical Release [regulation 40 CFR 68] because it has a refrigeration system that contains more than the threshold quantity (10,000 pounds) of anhydrous ammonia (CAS Number 7664-41-7).  Anhydrous ammonia (NH3), is a gas at ambient conditions.  The anhydrous ammonia (ammonia) refrigeration system is used to manufacture and store ice cream and related products.  It is a closed system that contains approximately 16,800 pounds (i.e., 3,400 gallons) of ammonia in various physical states (gas, liquid, and saturated vapor).  The largest vessel is the manufacturing high pressure receiver that operates at approximately 150 psig and can contain as much as 6,000 pounds of liquid ammonia (at its maximum safe fill volume of 80%).  However, during typical operation, the vessel contains only 1,900 pounds of ammonia.  Most of the ammonia equipment is located indoors.  The condensing towers, receiver, and some piping runs are located outdoors.
Ammonia is the oldest and most common refrigerant in general industrial use throughout the world.  It is a high capacity refrigerant that operates at reasonable pressure.  Although exposure to ammonia is irritating and potentially toxic in large doses, personnel exposure to more than a small leak is rare because ammonia operates within a closed system of vessels, piping, and equipment.  In addition, ammonia can be easily detected by smell at levels well below its toxic endpoint.
1.2 PROCESS DESCRIPTION
The anhydrous ammonia refrigeration system at the Decatur plant consists of two, separate subsystems--the "manufacturing system" and the "mezzanine system".  These two subsystems are connected together by piping, but are typically isolated from each other and operated independently.  The connections are usually only opened to transfer ammonia between the

systems.  
The entire system contains approximately 16,800 pounds of ammonia in various states (gas, liquid, and saturated vapor).  Cooling is accomplished by changing the pressure of the ammonia and expanding it from a lower, to a higher, pressure.
The manufacturing system is a two-stage system consisting of a high (pressure) side and a low side.  The mezzanine system is single-stage, but operates at the same suction pressure as the low side of the manufacturing system.
Liquid ammonia is received by truck into a nurse tank.  On occasion, when ammonia must be added to either system, it is transferred from the nurse tank.
1.2.1 Manufacturing System
The high stage compressor suction for the manufacturing system draws from the intercooler/high accumulator (booster discharge) at an intermediate pressure of about 25 psig.  This accumulator traps suction from the room evaporator coils, glycol chiller, and refrigerated storage tanks and returns its excess liquid to the low accumulator.
Ammonia suction from the low side (low pressure and, therefore, low temperature) at about 0 psig or below is collected in the low accumulator before entering the booster compressors (boosters).  The low side load units in the manufacturing system include the ice cream freezers, the Amerio liquid recirculation tank (cycle center), and the Amerio plate hardener.  Excess liquid from the low accumulator is transferred back to the high pressure receiver.
The discharge from the high side compressors (hot gas at 150 psig) is vented to roof-mounted cooling towers.  A portion of the hot gas is also used for defrosting of certain units and operation of a pumper drum for the slop tank.
The condensed liquid from the cooling towers drains into the high pressure receiver where it is then fed (by pressure) to the high side load units.  Condensed liquid is also fed to a liquid cooler (mounted inside the intercooler) before being used by the low-side load units.
1.2.2 Mezzanine System
The mezzanine system us

es three screw-type compressors which operate at a suction pressure of less than 0 psig and a discharge pressure of 150 psig.  Unlike the manufacturing system, the mezzanine does not have an intermediate pressure stage of 25 psig and all load units operate on the low side.  These load units include six air handling units used to maintain storage freezers at temperatures of -20oF to -40oF.
The hot gas from the mezzanine compressors is condensed to liquid in roof-mounted cooling towers.  Some hot gas is also used for defrosting.  The liquid drains vertically from the condensing towers, through a thermosyphon receiver, and into the high pressure receiver (HPR).  The liquid from the HPR is fed (by pressure) through three pre-coolers before going out to three of the six load units.  Pre-cooled liquid is also used to cool the screw compressors.  Oil for the screw compressors is cooled by recirculating liquid ammonia around the oil separator for each compressor.  The liquid ammonia is recirculated by the siphon effect caused by the condensed liquid draining through the thermosyphon receiver.
Low-side suction returning from the mezzanine load units is collected in the cycle center (accumulator) before entering the compressors.  Excess liquid is pumped to the remaining load units.
1.3 SAFETY SYSTEMS
Various safety systems are part of the anhydrous ammonia refrigeration system.  These include pressure relief valves, engine room ventilation, and safety interlocks.  
Safety relief valves (SRVs) protect the compressor discharge, condensors, pumper drums, suction accumulators, intercooler, and liquid recirculation system from overpressurization.  SRVs on the compressor discharge and condensers are set at 250 psig.  SRVs for the suction vessels are set at 150 psig.
Safety interlocks include high pressure and high temperature alarms and cut-outs for the compressors, as well as high level floats and/or sensors for the vessels.  If a discharge pressure of 185 psig is reached in the s

alternative-release scenarios required by 40 CFR 68.  To help minimize the probability and severity of an ammonia release, a prevention program that satisfies the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), Process Safety Management (PSM) of Highly Hazardous Chemicals  standard (29 CFR 1910.119) has been implemented.  The key components of the prevention program are summarized below:
A? The development, documentation, and operator availability of critical process safety information regarding the hazards of ammonia, the design basis of the system, and the equipment.  This information is used to fully understand and safely operate the ammonia refrigeration system.
A? The development of an extensive employee participation program, which includes employees from all levels of the organization and from all areas within the plant (i.e., production and maintenance).  This program also assures that employees that utilize the ammonia system and are most knowledgeable about it are best able to easily, effectively, and regularly recommend changes or improvements which enhance safety.
A? The performance of a formal process hazard analysis (PHA), using the "What-ifA?" technique.  A team with expertise in engineering, operations, maintenance, and safety evaluated the existing refrigeration system in depth and developed recommendations to improve the safety and operability of the system.  The PHA addressed:  (1) process hazards; (2) previous incidents; (3) engineering and administrative controls applicable to the hazards; (4) the consequence of control failure; (5) facility siting; (6) human factors; and (7) a qualitative evaluation of possible safety and health effects of control system failures.  The PHA will be updated and revalidated every five years.
A? Written operating procedures (Ops) were prepared to provide the basis for proper and safe operation of the ammonia refrigeration system.  The Ops include procedures for normal operation, startup, shutdown, emergency o

peration, and emergency shutdown.  They also describe safe operating limits for temperature and pressure, the consequences of operating outside these safe operating limits, and a description of safety systems and how they operate.
A? Refrigeration system operators receive refresher training at least every three years.  The training content is based upon the process safety information and operating procedures.  The training program ensures that the operators understand the nature and causes of problems arising from system operations and serves to increase awareness with respect to the hazards particular to ammonia and the refrigeration process.
A? Formal authorization systems (i.e., management of change procedure, pre-startup safety review) are in place to ensure that system changes or expansions are as safe as the original design and that an independent recheck, prior to start-up, confirms that the changes are consistent with the engineering design and safety requirements.  
A? Events that might (or did) cause an accidental or unexpected release of ammonia are subjected to a formal investigation.  The objective of the investigation is to correct deficiencies in such a way as to prevent recurrence.
A? Contractors that are hired to work on, or adjacent to, the refrigeration system are "pre-qualified" based upon their knowledge of ammonia refrigeration, understanding of applicable codes and standards, and their demonstrated ability to work safely.  
A? Prior to the performance of any hot work (i.e., spark or flame producing operations such as welding, cutting, brazing, grinding), management must approve the work by executing a written hot work authorization permit to verify that precautions to prevent fire have been implemented.
A? Periodic formal walk-throughs occur to find unusual or increasing vibration, incipient leaks, or other indications of potential upsets or failures that could lead to a release.
A? Replacement of all pressure relief valves occurs every five y

ears.
A? Numerous safety systems, including pressure relief valves, ammonia vessel level controls, and safety interlocks are used in the refrigeration system.
A? Periodic inspection and calibration is performed on liquid level sensors, temperature and pressure instruments, switches and shutdown devices that have safety implications.
A? Periodic inspections are performed for major powered equipment, including compressors, pumps and large fans, bearings, couplings, shaft seals, mountings, etc., for vibration or incipient mechanical failure.
A? Proper design, including adherence to recognized safety codes.
A? Adherence to fire codes and preparation for fires, storms, or events which could impact the ammonia system.
A? Planning with the local fire department to ensure a rapid response to potential incidents involving the system or external events, such as storms or tornadoes.
A? Prevention program compliance audits are performed to verify that the elements are being properly implemented.  Any deficiency found in an audit is corrected.
 
3.0 ACCIDENT HISTORY
There have been no accidental releases of ammonia at the facility in the last five years (since June 1999) that have resulted in death, injury, or significant property damage on-site or off-site death, injury, evacuation, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage. 
 
4.0 EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
The facility has implemented a detailed written Emergency Action Plan (EAP).  The EAP is intended to address all emergencies at the facility, in addition to incidents related to a release of ammonia.
The EAP includes awareness and response training for employees, coordination with the local fire department, and evacuation of the facility.  The plan details what personal protective equipment and spill response equipment is available; identifies specific individuals, their 24-hour telephone numbers, and their responsibilities; identifies procedures for emergency medical care; and refers to other pertinent

elements of the management system (i.e., standard operating procedures).
 
5.0 PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
The prevention program that is described in Section 2.0 of this Executive Summary is a management system that is designed to proactively identify, evaluate, and reduce the potential for a chlorine release and/or a release's impact or consequence, due to failures in process, procedures, and equipment.  As safety improvements are identified by the management system they are evaluated and, where appropriate, implemented.  For example, the facility may implement the following changes to further improve the safety of the process:
A? Additional training,
A? Periodic repair and replacement of equipment, and
A? Continued implementation and improvement of the PSM program
